Privet: A Privacy-Preserving Vertical Federated Learning Service for Gradient Boosted Decision Tables

Yifeng Zheng, Shuangqing Xu, Songlei Wang, Yansong Gao, and Zhongyun Hua Yifeng Zheng, Shuangqing Xu, Songlei Wang, and Zhongyun Hua are with the School of Computer Science and Technology, Harbin Institute of Technology, Shenzhen, Guangdong 518055, China (e-mail: yifeng.zheng@hit.edu.cn, shuangqing.xu@outlook.com, songlei.wang@outlook.com, huazhongyun@hit.edu.cn). Yansong Gao is with Data61, CSIRO, Sydney, Australia (e-mail: gao.yansong@hotmail.com). Corresponding author: Zhongyun Hua.
Abstract

Vertical federated learning (VFL) has recently emerged as an appealing distributed paradigm empowering multi-party collaboration for training high-quality models over vertically partitioned datasets. Gradient boosting has been popularly adopted in VFL, which builds an ensemble of weak learners (typically decision trees) to achieve promising prediction performance. Recently there have been growing interests in using decision table as an intriguing alternative weak learner in gradient boosting, due to its simpler structure, good interpretability, and promising performance. In the literature, there have been works on privacy-preserving VFL for gradient boosted decision trees, but no prior work has been devoted to the emerging case of decision tables. Training and inference on decision tables are different from that the case of generic decision trees, not to mention gradient boosting with decision tables in VFL. In light of this, we design, implement, and evaluate Privet, the first system framework enabling privacy-preserving VFL service for gradient boosted decision tables. Privet delicately builds on lightweight cryptography and allows an arbitrary number of participants holding vertically partitioned datasets to securely train gradient boosted decision tables. Extensive experiments over several real-world datasets and synthetic datasets demonstrate that Privet achieves promising performance, with utility comparable to plaintext centralized learning.

Index Terms:
Vertical federated learning service, multi-party collaboration, gradient boosting, decision table, privacy preservation

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) has recently emerged as a fascinating distributed machine learning paradigm that greatly empowers multi-party collaboration for mining value over data federation [1, 2, 3, 4]. It allows distributed individual training datasets to be kept locally, and only intermediate outputs from the training algorithm are shared out for aggregation. According to how data is distributed among the participants in FL, there are two types of FL: horizontal federated learning (HFL) [5, 6] and vertical federated learning (VFL) [7, 8]. HFL addresses the scenario where the participants share the same feature space but hold disjoint sets of samples/instances, which generally suits the case that participants are individual customers. In contrast, VFL targets the scenario where each participant has the same set of samples/instances yet owns data for different features, which is more common when the participants are business organizations/enterprises. For example, as illustrated in Fig. 1, the participants hold datasets that have the same row indexes (corresponding to the same set of instances) but different non-overlapping column indexes (corresponding to different features). In this paper, we focus on the VFL setting, which has received increasing attentions in the collaboration of different business organizations/enterprises in recent years [8, 9].

For model training in the VFL setting, the gradient boosting technique has received wide attentions [10, 8, 7, 11, 9] and has seen popular adoption for empowering a wide range of fields, such as web search ranking, online advertisement, and fraud detection [12, 13, 14]. Gradient boosting builds an ensemble of weak learners, which are typically (generic) decision trees, to achieve promising prediction performance. While decision tree is usually used as the weak learner in gradient boosting, in recent years there has been a fast-growing trend to use decision table [15] as an intriguing alternative [16, 17, 18, 19]. Many works [16, 17, 20, 21] have shown that gradient boosted decision tables yields promising performance on various tasks and achieves great inference efficiency over generic decision trees. In addition, some famous open-source gradient boosting libraries [22, 17] have also recently provided the support for using decision table as the weak learner in gradient boosting.

As demonstrated in Fig. 2, a Dğ·D-dimensional decision table at a high level consists of Dğ·D Boolean tests and 2Dsuperscript2ğ·2^{D} output values. It can also be treated as a special full binary decision tree, called oblivious tree. In contrast with generic decision tree which has different Boolean tests at different internal nodes at the same level, the internal nodes at the same level of an oblivious tree share the same Boolean test defined with the same feature and threshold. Despite the similarly equivalent tree structure, it is worth noting that the algorithm for training oblivious tree is different from that for generic decision tree [23, 24]. Specifically, decision trees are typically trained through recursive algorithms [23, 24], while decision tables are trained through iterative algorithms following the top-down construction [15, 16]. Given tree depth Dğ·D, the shape of a generic decision tree is uncertain because it needs to process samples associated with the current node to determine whether to split this node. In contrast, we can not recursively build a decision table because all the samples in the dataset need to be processed to select the optimal split for each level of the decision table. Besides, given depth Dğ·D, the shape of an oblivious tree is fixed and the number of operations like node splitting and output value calculation is also fixed. In addition, the inference process on an oblivious tree is also different from that on a generic decision tree[16, 18] (see Section 3.1 for more detailed discussion).

In the literature, while there have been several studies on privacy-preserving VFL with gradient boosted decision trees (GBDT) [10, 8, 7], no prior work has explored privacy-preserving VFL with gradient boosted decision tables. As mentioned above, even training and inference on decision table are different from the case of generic decision tree, not to mention gradient boosting with decision table as the weak learner in the VFL setting. Therefore, these prior works cannot be directly applied to support privacy-preserving training and inference of gradient boosted decision tables in VFL. In addition, it is noted that these prior works are also confronted with limitations such as exposing sensitive intermediate results (e.g., sum of gradients) [10, 7], supporting training only among two participants [8] (see Section 2 for more detailed discussion).

In light of the above, we propose Privet, which, to our best knowledge, is the first system framework enabling privacy-preserving VFL service for training gradient boosted decision tables over distributed datasets. Privet ambitiously supports an arbitrary number of participants to collaboratively train gradient boosted decision tables, while allowing them to keep their data locally and offering strong protection on the sensitive intermediate outputs throughout the training process. Privet builds on lightweight secret sharing techniques to develop customized protocols securely realizing the key components required by training gradient boosted decision tables in the VFL setting.

Specifically, through an in-depth examination on the training process of gradient boosted decision tables, we manage to decompose the holistic secure design in the VFL setting into the design of a series of secure components run in a distributed manner among the participants, including secure node splitting, secure Sigmoid evaluation, secure discretization, and secure distributed decision table inference. The delicate synergy of these secure components leads to the holistic protocol of Privet for privately training gradient boosted decision tables in the VFL setting. Through the customized secure protocol, Privet outputs gradient boosted decision tables that are distributed among the involved participants, where each participant only holds a part of the model. Subsequently, secure inference on the ensemble of learned decision tables can also be well supported in a distributed manner among the participants. We implement and evaluate Privetâ€™s protocols extensively over several real-world datasets as well as synthetic datasets. The results demonstrate that Privet presents promising performance in computation and communication. Meanwhile, the utility of the trained models in Privet is comparable to that in the plaintext centralized learning setting.

We highlight our contributions as follows.

  • â€¢

    We present Privet, which, to our best knowledge, is the first system framework enabling privacy-preserving VFL service for gradient boosted decision tables. Privet allows an arbitrary number of participants holding vertically partitioned distributed datasets to securely train gradient boosted decision tables in a distributed manner, offering strong protection for sensitive individual data as well as for intermediate outputs.

  • â€¢

    We devise a series of tailored secure components based on lightweight secret sharing techniques that run in a distributed manner among multiple participants with promising efficiency and utility, catering for the computation required by securely training gradient boosted decision tables in the VFL setting.

  • â€¢

    We make an implementation of the proposed protocols and conduct an extensive evaluation over three real-world public datasets and three synthetic datasets. The experiment results demonstrate that Privet has promising performance, achieving model utility comparable to plaintext centralized learning.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 discusses the related work. Section 3 introduces some preliminaries. Section 4 gives a system overview. Section 5 presents the design of Privet. The security analysis is presented in Section 6, followed by the experiments in Section 7. Section 8 concludes the whole paper.

2 Related Work

Securely learning gradient boosted decision trees under HFL. Due to the problems of data isolation and data privacy, FL has emerged as a new privacy-preserving machine learning paradigm. Several existing works [5, 25, 6] have been focused on privacy-preserving gradient boosted decision trees (GBDT) under the HFL setting, which assume that data are horizontally partitioned between participants. Among them, the work [6] rely on use of secure aggregation and differential privacy to provide a privacy guarantee. The work [25] leverages secure hardware[26] to build private GBDT under HFL. Different from these works, our work targets privacy-preserving gradient boosting systems under the VFL setting.

Securely learning gradient boosted decision trees under VFL. To cater for the need to collaboratively build models between different organizations that hold data on the same set of samples but for different features, VFL has received increasing attention in recent years. The works [10, 8, 7] consider vertical federated gradient boosted decision trees, which are most related to ours. In particular, SecureBoost [10] is the first work on privacy-preserving GBDT over vertically partitioned data, which uses homomorphic encryption to preserve data privacy. However, it has limited security guarantee because intermediate information (e.g., the sum of gradients in a bucket) is revealed during the training process. Moreover, homomorphic encryption involves heavy cryptographic operations and requires large memory, which results in low training efficiency. The works[8, 7] improve SecureBoost [10] in terms of efficiency via multi-party computation (MPC) techniques. Specifically, the work [8] proposes a secure GBDT system leveraging the additive secret sharing technique [27]. However, their proposed system is only designed for the two-party setting. Xie et al. [7] deal with the issue to support secure multi-party training. However, since they adopt large-scale matrix multiplication in the secret sharing domain to discretize secret-shared gradients into buckets, their scheme requires more communication and computation overhead compared to [8]. Moreover, the design in [7] has notable privacy leakages, e.g., the intermediate inference results of all training samples are leaked to the participant who holds the label set because it relies on this participant to conduct inference.

We also note that all these works [10, 8, 7] are aimed at supporting secure training and inference for gradient boosting with generic decision trees under VFL. In recent years, the gradient boosted decision table technique has seen rapidly growing adoption in various applications, such as learning to rank (LTR) [18, 21, 28], recommendation systems[16, 29], and medical diagnosis [30, 31]. Although the training of decision tree and decision table has some similarities, e.g., both of them need permutation protocols, their learning algorithms are different inherently. Thus the works [10, 8, 7] cannot directly support secure gradient boosting over decision tables under VFL. In comparison with them, Privet focuses on securely supporting privacy-preserving VFL for gradient boosted decision tables. In addition, Privet departs from them by achieving comparable utility to plaintext, concealing intermediate information for strong privacy, and supporting an arbitrary number of participants.

Secure decision tree learning supporting both horizontally and vertically partitioned data. There are some works [32, 33, 34] which can support secure decision tree learning on both horizontally and vertically partitioned data in an outsourcing setting. Specifically, the work [32] considers a setting where data owners secret-share all their data among three servers and designs a protocol to enable the three servers to securely perform an adapted C4.5 decision tree learning algorithm. The work [34] proposes protocols to train decision trees for the Random Forest model, which similarly considers a setting where the data owners secret-share all their data among two extra non-colluding computing parties. In [33], Deforth et al. focus on building private gradient boosted decision trees and consider a scenario where data owners secret-share their data among a set of computing parties which may also be an extra set of servers. In contrast with these works that outsource the data and computation, Privet does not require such an extra set of non-colluding servers which may not be an easy assumption to meet in practice. Meanwhile, Privet allows the raw data of each participant to stay local throughout the whole training process, fitting the salient feature of FL.

3 Preliminaries

3.1 Decision Table

The jğ‘—j-th element of ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{i} is the value of an input attribute Xjsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘—X_{j}. A Dğ·D-dimensional decision table consists of Dğ·D Boolean tests and 2Dsuperscript2ğ·2^{D} output values. A Boolean test is of the form Xj<tsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘—ğ‘¡X_{j}<t, which outputs 111 if the jğ‘—j-th element in a given input tuple is less than a threshold tğ‘¡t and 00 otherwise.

As illustrated in Fig. 2, a Dğ·D-dimensional decision table is equivalent to a full binary tree with D+1ğ·1D+1 levels, where each internal node from the 00-th level (for the root node) to the (Dâˆ’1)ğ·1(D-1)-th level has a Boolean test; each edge is assigned the outcome of its source nodeâ€™s test and each leaf node at the Dğ·D-th level is associated with an output value. Such equivalent tree is called oblivious tree, because all internal nodes at the same level share the same test, as opposed to generic decision trees that have different tests at the same level. More specifically, the test at the dğ‘‘d-th level of an oblivious tree could be represented as Fd<tdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘F_{d}<t_{d}, where dâˆˆ[0,Dâˆ’1]ğ‘‘0ğ·1d\in[0,D-1], the split feature Fdâˆˆ{X1,â‹¯,XJ}subscriptğ¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‹1â‹¯subscriptğ‘‹ğ½F_{d}\in\{X_{1},\cdots,X_{J}\}, and tdsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘t_{d} is the split threshold. The special structure of oblivious tree results in its different training and inference methods from non-oblivious trees like CART [23]. In [15], Kohavi et al. first introduce a top-down construction of oblivious trees and use information gain as the evaluation metric to find the optimal test at each level. Different evaluation metrics are used in later studies, like mean squared error (MSE)[16] and Newtonâ€™s method[17].

We follow the top-down construction in [15, 16] to train oblivious trees. Algorithm 1 shows the process of training an oblivious tree, which produces Dğ·D tests and 2Dsuperscript2ğ·2^{D} output values. The learning algorithm starts from the 00-th level and builds an oblivious tree level by level iteratively. At level 111, an optimal test F1<t1subscriptğ¹1subscriptğ‘¡1F_{1}<t_{1} is found and ğ’ŸF0<t0,ğ’ŸF0â‰¥t0subscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğ¹0subscriptğ‘¡0subscriptğ’Ÿsubscriptğ¹0subscriptğ‘¡0\mathcal{D}_{F_{0}<t_{0}},\mathcal{D}_{F_{0}\geq t_{0}} are each partitioned into two subsets according to F1<t1subscriptğ¹1subscriptğ‘¡1F_{1}<t_{1}. The same procedure is repeated until all the Dğ·D tests are learned. In this way, the tree structure is kept full and symmetric, and we have |ğ’®l|=2lsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘™superscript2ğ‘™|\mathcal{S}^{l}|=2^{l} at level lğ‘™l, where each set in ğ’®lsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘™\mathcal{S}^{l} is associated with a node at this level. When reaching the Dğ·D-th level, the output values will be calculated for the leaf nodes. Finally, an oblivious tree composed of Dğ·D tests and 2Dsuperscript2ğ·2^{D} output values is learned.

The optimal test at each level is found via the routine ğ–¿ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½â€‹_â€‹ğ—Œğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–¿ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½_ğ—Œğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{find\_split} by evaluating the candidate tests. Evaluation of the candidate tests can be made through different metrics. In Privet, we follow the popular second-order approximation method [35, 17] to evaluate tests because the decision tables in our work are trained sequentially for a gradient boosting system. Besides, the output values of decision tables can also be calculated following the gradient boosting theory, which will be introduced shortly in Section 3.2.

As presented in Algorithm 1, training a decision table (oblivious tree) is an iterative process, while decision trees are typically trained through recursive algorithms[23, 24]. Given tree depth Dğ·D, the shape of a generic decision tree is uncertain because it needs to process samples associated with the current node to judge whether to split this node. However, the shape of an oblivious tree is predetermined at a given dimension Dğ·D. To select the optimal split at each level, all the samples in the dataset are required to be processed. Besides, the number of operations involved in training an oblivious tree, such as ğ–¿ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½â€‹_â€‹ğ—Œğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–¿ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½_ğ—Œğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{find\_split} and output value calculation, is fixed.

Decision table outperforms generic decision tree in inference efficiency significantly. As illustrated in Fig. 2, each leaf node of an oblivious tree (the right sub-figure in Fig. 2) corresponds to a Boolean sequence and the comparisons required by Dğ·D tests could be parallelized. In contrast, inference in a regular decision tree is made by traversing the tree from the root node to a leaf node, which means the direction of the inference path after the current node depends on the test result of this node. Note that while the evaluation of each decision node in generic decision tree inference can be parallelized, it is still necessary to traverse the tree from the root node sequentially so as to identify the correct leaf node that produces the inference result. For example, as shown in the left sub-figure in Fig. 2, even if we parallelize the evaluation of each decision node, i.e., we obtain the sequence of test results [0,0,1,1,0]00110[0,0,1,1,0] by evaluating the 00-th split to the 444-th split simultaneously, we cannot directly identify which leaf node is finally chosen using [0,0,1,1,0]00110[0,0,1,1,0]. On the contrary, decision table inference is free of such sequential traversal [16, 17, 18]. As illustrated in the right sub-figure in Fig. 2, once the sequence comprised of Boolean test result at each level is obtained, the inference result can be immediately obtained because this Boolean sequence is also the identifier of a leaf node.

Additionally, it is noted that in gradient boosting systems, the number, size, and depth of generic decision trees are not necessarily smaller than decision tables when achieving the same accuracy because they are both weak learners and only require weak predictability. As reported in prior work [16], compared with gradient boosted decision trees with the number of trees T=50ğ‘‡50T=50 and tree depth D=7ğ·7D=7, gradient boosted decision tables only requires depth D=6ğ·6D=6 given the same number of oblivious trees T=50ğ‘‡50T=50 to achieve similar accuracy performance. Furthermore, it is noted that with the same depth Dğ·D, a decision table only needs storage of Dğ·D decision nodes (one for each level), while a generic decision tree may require storage of up to 2Dâˆ’1superscript2ğ·12^{D}-1 decision nodes [16, 18].

3.2 Gradient Boosted Decision Tables

A gradient boosting system is built by training a set of weak learners sequentially based on the boosting algorithm[35, 36]. For the given dataset ğ’Ÿ={ğ±i,yi}i=0Nâˆ’1ğ’Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘1ğ‘–0\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i},y_{i}\}^{N-1}_{i=0}, a gradient boosting system sums the inference results of Tğ‘‡T weak learners to produce the ultimate inference result for the iğ‘–i-th sample[36]: y^i(T)=âˆ‘t=1Tftâ€‹(ğ±i)superscriptsubscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘–\hat{y}_{i}^{(T)}=\sum_{t=1}^{T}f_{t}(\mathbf{x}_{i}), where ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t} corresponds to the model of the tğ‘¡t-th weak learner. In gradient boosted decision tables[16, 17], ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t} corresponds to a decision table. A given sample will be classified into the leaf nodes in the decision tables according to the tests in them. Its ultimate inference result is calculated by summing up the output values associated with the corresponding leaf nodes.

The essence of gradient boosting algorithm comes from how it boosts the weak learners sequentially. After training tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1 weak learners, the tğ‘¡t-th model ftsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡f_{t} is needed to be trained and added to minimize the following objective function[35]:

This notation is also used to denote the index set associated with the internal node, e.g., we write â„qsuperscriptâ„ğ‘\mathcal{I}^{q} for node qğ‘q. Then, after removing the constant terms, Eq. 1 can be rewritten as[35]:

â„’~(t)superscript~â„’ğ‘¡\displaystyle\tilde{\mathcal{L}}^{(t)} =âˆ‘k=0Lâˆ’1[(âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„kgi)â€‹wk+12â€‹(âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„khi+Î»)â€‹wk2]+Î³â€‹Labsentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜0ğ¿1delimited-[]subscriptğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜12subscriptğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘–ğœ†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜2ğ›¾ğ¿\displaystyle=\sum_{k=0}^{L-1}[(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}^{k}}g_{i})w_{k}+\frac{1}{2}(\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}^{k}}h_{i}+\lambda)w_{k}^{2}]+\gamma L (2)

When the tree stops growing, wksubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜w_{k} and the minimum loss of the current tree are calculated by [35]:

Suppose we have learned bğ‘b tests from the level 00 to the level (bâˆ’1)ğ‘1(b-1) of a Dğ·D-dimensional decision table and we need to find an optimal test at level bğ‘b. 4 System Overview

4.1 System Architecture

Fig. 3 illustrates the system architecture of Privet, which targets the vertical federated learning scenario. In Privet, multiple participants (e.g., business organizations and institutions) want to collaboratively train gradient boosted decision tables over vertically partitioned data. Under such setting, a dataset consisting of Nğ‘N samples (each is associated with a feature vector and a label) is vertically partitioned among nğ‘›n participants P1,P2,â‹¯,Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n}. Each participant Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šP_{m} holds its respective dataset ğ’ŸmNÃ—Jm={ğ±iJm}i=0Nâˆ’1subscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ‘1ğ‘–0\mathcal{D}^{N\times J_{m}}_{m}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}^{J_{m}}\}^{N-1}_{i=0}, where Jmsubscriptğ½ğ‘šJ_{m} denotes the number of features owned by Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šP_{m} and is subject to âˆ‘m=1nJm=Jsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘š1ğ‘›subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ½\sum_{m=1}^{n}J_{m}=J, ğ±iJmsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ½ğ‘š\mathbf{x}_{i}^{J_{m}} represents the iğ‘–i-th sample of ğ’ŸmNÃ—Jmsubscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ‘š\mathcal{D}^{N\times J_{m}}_{m}. Let ğ²={yi}i=0Nâˆ’1ğ²subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘1ğ‘–0\mathbf{y}=\{y_{i}\}^{N-1}_{i=0} be the set of sample labels. Following prior works on VFL [10, 7, 8], we consider two roles for the participants: active participant (AP) and passive participant (PP). In particular, there is one AP that holds a local dataset as well as the label set ğ²ğ²\mathbf{y}; and the remaining participants are PPs, each only holding a local dataset. For simplicity, in Privet, we assume the participant Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{n} is the AP.

Throughout the secure training process in Privet, each participant keeps its feature data locally. The Boolean tests and output values of the decision tables are securely learned in Privet, in such a manner that no participant knows the complete models. In particular, Privet follows a setting similar to the works [10, 7, 8, 11] under VFL, where each participant learns partial information of the learned models. Specifically, in Privet, all the participants know the split feature of each test in a decision table of the ensemble and who owns this feature, but only the participant owning this feature knows the split threshold of the test. Formally, for the learned test Fd<tdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘F_{d}<t_{d} at the dğ‘‘d-th level (dâˆˆ[0,Dâˆ’1]ğ‘‘0ğ·1d\in[0,D-1]) of the tğ‘¡t-th decision table (tâˆˆ[1,T]ğ‘¡1ğ‘‡t\in[1,T]) in the ensemble, the split feature Fdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘F_{d} is revealed to all participants but the threshold tdsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘t_{d} is only known by the participant owing the feature data corresponding to Fdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘F_{d}. In addition, all the output values of leaf nodes are produced in secret-shared form among all participants.

4.2 Threat Model

Privet is designed under the semi-honest adversary model, as is common in state-of-the-art security designs on vertical federated learning [8, 41]. Specifically, in Privet, each participant is assumed to faithfully follow the protocol specification but may try to deduce other participantsâ€™ private information from the messages they receive. It is noted that though we consider two roles AP and PP for the participants, no additional trust is assumed regarding the AP. The semi-honest adversary model should be reasonable in practice because VFL aims at breaking down the data silos between business organizations, where the behavior of each organization is strictly enforced by privacy regulations[42]. We also consider that a static adversary may corrupt a subset of Ï„ğœ\tau participants (Ï„â‰¤nâˆ’1ğœğ‘›1\tau\leq n-1). That is, a static adversary may choose a subset of the participants to corrupt before the VFL procedure and the chosen participants remain corrupted during the VFL procedure.

Under the above threat model, Privet aims to guarantee that a semi-honest participant individually cannot learn any other participantâ€™s local data and learned partial model (tests and output values of each decision table in the ensemble) throughout the VFL procedure. In case of collusion among a subset of the participants, Privet strives to still ensure that the honest participantsâ€™ private information is protected against the corrupted participants. Like prior works [8, 32, 10], Privet does not hide the data-independent generic parameters, such as the dimension Dğ·D and the number of decision tables Tğ‘‡T.

5 The Design of Privet

5.1 Overview

We provide in Algorithm 2 an overview of the secure training framework in Privet, which inputs the vertically partitioned datasets {ğ’ŸmNÃ—Jm}m=1nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘š1\{\mathcal{D}^{N\times J_{m}}_{m}\}^{n}_{m=1} and the label set ğ²ğ²\mathbf{y} from the participants, and outputs an ensemble â„°â„°\mathcal{E} of distributed decision tables among the participants. At the beginning, the secret-shared inference result âŸ¦ğ²^(0)âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscript^ğ²0\llbracket{\mathbf{\hat{y}}^{(0)}}\rrbracket is initialized as the secret sharing âŸ¦ğŸNâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscript0ğ‘\llbracket\mathbf{0}_{N}\rrbracket (Nğ‘N denotes the length of the secret-shared vector), and the AP distributes the secret shares of its label set to other participants. After that, Tğ‘‡T distributed decision tables are securely built sequentially in Tğ‘‡T rounds (lines 6-10).

We develop a secure decision table learning algorithm ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾\mathsf{SecTable} to support the secure training of a single (distributed) decision table in each round. ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾\mathsf{SecTable} consists of several secure components, including (i) secure node splitting ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SecSplit}, (ii) secure Sigmoid evaluation ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½\mathsf{SecSigmoid}, and (iii) secure discretization ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼\mathsf{SecDisc}. The secure node splitting component ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SecSplit} (Section 5.2.1) is to securely split the nodes at a certain level and partition the index sets associated with these nodes without revealing the partitioned index sets. The secure Sigmoid evaluation component ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½\mathsf{SecSigmoid} (Section 5.2.2) inputs a secret-shared value and calculates the Sigmoid function in the secret sharing domain. The secure discretization component ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼\mathsf{SecDisc} (Section 5.2.3) is to securely rearrange the secret-shared gradients according to the local permutations owned by each participant and then group them into buckets. Through the synergy of these components, ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾\mathsf{SecTable} allows the participants to securely train a distributed decision table in each round, for which we will give the details in Section 5.2.4.

After securely training a distributed decision table in a certain round, secure inference needs to be conducted, of which the result will be added to previous inference results (line 9) for use in ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾\mathsf{SecTable} in the next round. To this end, we develop a secure distributed decision table inference protocol ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer} (Section 5.3), which inputs each participantâ€™s local data and partial model to produce secret-shared inference results without leaking their data and partial model. It is worth noting that ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer} can also be used to support secure inference for new data after the completion of the whole training process.

5.2 Secure Distributed Decision Table Training

5.2.1 Secure Node Splitting

An oblivious tree grows to a new level by splitting each node at the current level into two child nodes. In plaintext centralized decision table training (Algorithm 1), node splitting is performed by partitioning the samples associated with the node to be split. However, in VFL, the partitioning of samples must be revealed to all participants because the training dataset is vertically partitioned and all participants hold the same samples. For instance, given a test â€œHâ€‹eâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹hâ€‹t<180ğ»ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡180Height<180â€, the participant owning feature data of â€œHâ€‹eâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹hâ€‹tğ»ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡Heightâ€ needs to tell other participants which samples are less than 180180180 and which samples are greater than 180180180, which will leak each sampleâ€™s range of â€œHâ€‹eâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹hâ€‹tğ»ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡Heightâ€ and raise critical privacy concerns.

To avoid this leakage, we design a secure node splitting component ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SecSplit}. Inspired by existing works[41, 8, 7], we utilize indicator vectors to conduct secure node splitting for each level of the decision table. At a high level, Privet associates the kğ‘˜k-th node (kâˆˆ[0,2dâˆ’1]ğ‘˜0superscript2ğ‘‘1k\in[0,2^{d}-1]) at the dğ‘‘d-th level (dâˆˆ[0,Dâˆ’1]ğ‘‘0ğ·1d\in[0,D-1]) of the oblivious decision tree with a first-order gradient vector âŸ¦ğ k,dâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\llbracket\mathbf{g}^{k,d}\rrbracket and a second-order gradient vector âŸ¦ğ¡k,dâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ¡ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\llbracket\mathbf{h}^{k,d}\rrbracket, each containing Nğ‘N elements that are secret-shared among all participants P1,P2,â‹¯,Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n}. If the iğ‘–i-th sample is partitioned into this node, the iğ‘–i-th element in âŸ¦ğ k,dâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\llbracket\mathbf{g}^{k,d}\rrbracket and âŸ¦ğ¡k,dâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ¡ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\llbracket\mathbf{h}^{k,d}\rrbracket will be set as the iğ‘–i-th sampleâ€™s first and second-order gradients, respectively, otherwise the iğ‘–i-th element will be set as âŸ¦0âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§0\llbracket 0\rrbracket.

Algorithm 3 gives the procedure of secure node splitting. Firstly, participant Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l} who owns the optimal test Fd<tdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘F_{d}<t_{d} at the dğ‘‘d-th level locally generates left indicator vector ğ¯lsubscriptğ¯ğ‘™\mathbf{v}_{l} and right indicator vector ğ¯rsubscriptğ¯ğ‘Ÿ\mathbf{v}_{r} and then distributes their secret sharings (denoted by âŸ¦ğ¯lâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ¯ğ‘™\llbracket\mathbf{v}_{l}\rrbracket and âŸ¦ğ¯râŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ¯ğ‘Ÿ\llbracket\mathbf{v}_{r}\rrbracket) to other participants (i.e., lines 3-10 in Algorithm 3). Upon receiving âŸ¦ğ¯lâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ¯ğ‘™\llbracket\mathbf{v}_{l}\rrbracket and âŸ¦ğ¯râŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ¯ğ‘Ÿ\llbracket\mathbf{v}_{r}\rrbracket, for the kğ‘˜k-th node at this level, P1,P2,â‹¯,Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n} update the first-order and second-order gradient vector of the kğ‘˜k-th nodeâ€™s left and right child nodes. The update is achieved with secure element-wise multiplication between secret-shared indicator vectors and gradient vectors (i.e., lines 11-16 in Algorithm 3). In this way, the index set processed by each node is hidden and the number of the samples processed by each node remains constant as Nğ‘N, which means an adversary cannot deduce any information from node splitting.

5.2.2 Secure Sigmoid Evaluation

There are mainly two challenges in securely calculating the Sigmoid function in the secret sharing domain. Firstly, how to compute the division âŸ¦xyâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\llbracket\frac{x}{y}\rrbracket given two secret-shared values âŸ¦xâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¥\llbracket x\rrbracket and âŸ¦yâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¦\llbracket y\rrbracket? Secondly, how to compute the exponentiation function âŸ¦exâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥\llbracket e^{x}\rrbracket given a secret-shared value âŸ¦xâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¥\llbracket x\rrbracket? Next, we introduce how Privet tackles the two challenges so as to allow the participants to securely calculate the Sigmoid function in the secret sharing domain. For the first challenge, we introduce a secure division component ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SDiv} by transforming the division calculation into a numerical optimization problem. Specifically, we note that the core obstacle of calculating âŸ¦xyâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\llbracket\frac{x}{y}\rrbracket given âŸ¦xâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¥\llbracket x\rrbracket and âŸ¦yâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¦\llbracket y\rrbracket is to calculate the secret-shared reciprocal âŸ¦1yâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§1ğ‘¦\llbracket\frac{1}{y}\rrbracket. Therefore, we first approximate 1y1ğ‘¦\frac{1}{y} by the iterative Newton-Raphson algorithm [43], following previous works [44, 45]: ziâ†2â€‹ziâˆ’1âˆ’yâ€‹ziâˆ’12â†subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–2subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–1ğ‘¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–12z_{i}\leftarrow 2z_{i-1}-yz_{i-1}^{2}, which will converge to znâ‰ˆ1ysubscriptğ‘§ğ‘›1ğ‘¦z_{n}\approx\frac{1}{y}. In Privet, we fix the initialization z0=1/Ysubscriptğ‘§01ğ‘Œz_{0}=1/Y, where Yğ‘ŒY is a sufficiently large value. Note that the approximation consists of basic subtraction and multiplication operations which are naturally supported in the secret sharing domain, given âŸ¦yâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¦\llbracket y\rrbracket, the secret-shared reciprocal âŸ¦1yâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§1ğ‘¦\llbracket\frac{1}{y}\rrbracket can be securely calculated. After securely calculating the reciprocal âŸ¦1yâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§1ğ‘¦\llbracket\frac{1}{y}\rrbracket, Privet multiplies âŸ¦xâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¥\llbracket x\rrbracket by âŸ¦1yâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§1ğ‘¦\llbracket\frac{1}{y}\rrbracket to obtain âŸ¦xyâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\llbracket\frac{x}{y}\rrbracket, i.e., âŸ¦xyâŸ§=âŸ¦xâŸ§â‹…âŸ¦1yâŸ§\llbracket\frac{x}{y}\rrbracket=\llbracket x\rrbracket\cdot\llbracket\frac{1}{y}\rrbracket.

For the second challenge, i.e., computing the exponentiation function âŸ¦exâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥\llbracket e^{x}\rrbracket given a secret-shared value âŸ¦xâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¥\llbracket x\rrbracket, we approximate exsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥e^{x} by limit characterization, inspired by [44]: exâ‰ˆ(1+x2n)2nsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥superscript1ğ‘¥superscript2ğ‘›superscript2ğ‘›e^{x}\approx(1+\frac{x}{2^{n}})^{2^{n}}, which provides a good approximation of exsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥e^{x}. Note that since the approximation consists of basic addition and multiplication operations which are naturally supported in the secret sharing domain, given âŸ¦xâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘¥\llbracket x\rrbracket, the secret-shared exponentiation âŸ¦exâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥\llbracket e^{x}\rrbracket can be securely calculated. However, we note that the approximation method requires 2nsuperscript2ğ‘›2^{n} chain multiplications, and thus requires 2nsuperscript2ğ‘›2^{n} rounds of online communication. The approximation method is inefficient in practice since the communication complexity grows exponentially. Therefore, Privet further reduces the exponential communication complexity to linear communication complexity. More specifically, we note that the computation in the approximation can be regarded as a2nsuperscriptğ‘superscript2ğ‘›a^{2^{n}} where a=1+x2nğ‘1ğ‘¥superscript2ğ‘›a=1+\frac{x}{2^{n}}. Therefore, given âŸ¦aâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘\llbracket a\rrbracket, Privet first securely calculates âŸ¦a2âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ‘2\llbracket a^{2}\rrbracket, which only requires one round of communication. After that, Privet regards the output as âŸ¦yâŸ§=âŸ¦a2âŸ§\llbracket y\rrbracket=\llbracket a^{2}\rrbracket followed by securely calculating âŸ¦y2âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ‘¦2\llbracket y^{2}\rrbracket, which also only requires one round of communication. Therefore, in this way, we can securely calculate âŸ¦a2nâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ‘superscript2ğ‘›\llbracket a^{2^{n}}\rrbracket in logâ¡2n=nsuperscript2ğ‘›ğ‘›\log 2^{n}=n rounds instead of 2nsuperscript2ğ‘›2^{n} rounds. Clearly, there is a trade-off between accuracy and efficiency in approximating exsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘¥e^{x} with (1+x2n)2nsuperscript1ğ‘¥superscript2ğ‘›superscript2ğ‘›(1+\frac{x}{2^{n}})^{2^{n}} for computation in the secret sharing domain. In principle increasing the value of nğ‘›n would lead to a more accurate approximation of the Sigmoid function. However, this also leads to increased computation and communication costs. Yet, as will be shown by our experiments, a small value of nğ‘›n (in our case, we set n=2ğ‘›2n=2) suffices to enable Privet to achieve the accuracy comparable to plaintext centralized learning.

Remark. In the literature, there exist some methods for approximating the Sigmoid function so as to support secure Sigmoid evaluation, including Taylor expansion[46], piece-wise approximation [27], and function approximation like fâ€‹(x)=0.5â€‹x1+|x|+0.5ğ‘“ğ‘¥0.5ğ‘¥1ğ‘¥0.5f(x)=\frac{0.5x}{1+|x|}+0.5 [8]. For the Taylor expansion method, it requires a small input parameter (very close to 0), which is hard to satisfy in machine learning. The piece-wise approximation method has no such requirement but suffers from notable accuracy loss[8]. The work that is most closely related to ours is due to Fang et al. [8], who apply another function approximation method to approximate the Sigmoid function, i.e., fâ€‹(x)=0.5â€‹x1+|x|+0.5ğ‘“ğ‘¥0.5ğ‘¥1ğ‘¥0.5f(x)=\frac{0.5x}{1+|x|}+0.5. However, their method still experienced non-trivial loss in accuracy in their securely trained XGBoost model. As reported in their experiments, the Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC) value would go up to 0.84463 from 0.82945 if they replace the secure Sigmoid approximation with plaintext Sigmoid computation. In contrast, as will be shown by the experiments in Section 7.2, our proposed ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½\mathsf{SecSigmoid} can achieve AUC values that are highly close to those obtained using plaintext centralized learning (e.g., the gap can be as small as 0.0005).

5.2.3 Secure Discretization

Discretization, also called bucketing, is a commonly used grouping method in large-scale machine learning [35, 22]. Specifically, discretization groups the samples into a small number of buckets so as to allow the model training to scale on larger datasets. Let BğµB denote the number of buckets in discretization, where Bâ‰ªNmuch-less-thanğµğ‘B\ll N and Nğ‘N is the number of samples. In gradient boosting, gradients are grouped into buckets and the sum of gradients in each bucket is calculated in the training stage[35, 22]. Typically, for each feature, the gradients are first permuted by a permutation Ï€ğœ‹\pi, which is obtained by sorting the values of this feature. Then the permuted gradients are partitioned into BğµB buckets. Obviously, the cost of training on BğµB buckets instead of Nğ‘N samples can be greatly reduced.

However, discretization is non-trivial in privacy-preserving machine learning. In existing MPC-based works[34, 33, 32], the training data is secret-shared among a fixed set of computing servers, and sorting the secret-shared training data for discretization requires a large number of secure comparison operations, which is expensive in the secret sharing domain. In Privet, the training data is vertically partitioned, and thus the sorting process can be achieved locally to reduce the overhead. However, it is still difficult to permute the secret-shared gradient vector by a permutation Ï€ğœ‹\pi held by a participant Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l} without revealing Ï€ğœ‹\pi to other participants.

To tackle the challenge, we propose a secure permutation algorithm ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†\mathsf{SecPerm} (shown in Algorithm 4), which stems from the correlated randomness (CR) scheme in [8]. Our tailored design ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†\mathsf{SecPerm} enables our secure discretization component ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼\mathsf{SecDisc} to outperform that in [8] in supporting an arbitrary number of participants. Fang et al. [8] design two MPC-based secure discretization methods. Specifically, they first propose a basic discretization method based on multiplications between secret-shared lagre-scale matrices. Then they obtain significant speedup over the basic method by utilizing CR to efficiently permute secret-shared gradients, and then group them. However, both the basic and improved methods in [8] only work under the two-party setting in VFL. The work [7] is the first MPC-based work supporting more than two participants in VFL with GBDT, but it simply follows the basic discretization method in [8]. In contrast, Privet tailors the improved discretization method from [8] to support an arbitrary number of participants, which is more efficient than the straightforward secret-shared lagre-scale matrix multiplication-based method from [7].

As shown in Algorithm 4, at the beginning of ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†\mathsf{SecPerm}, participants P1,P2,â‹¯,Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n} hold a secret-shared vector âŸ¦ğ±âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ±\llbracket\mathbf{x}\rrbracket and Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l} holds a permutation Ï€ğœ‹\pi. At the end of ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†\mathsf{SecPerm}, participants P1,P2,â‹¯,Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n} hold a secret-shared vector âŸ¦ğ®âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ®\llbracket\mathbf{u}\rrbracket where ğ®=Ï€â€‹(ğ±)ğ®ğœ‹ğ±\mathbf{u}=\pi(\mathbf{x}). ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†\mathsf{SecPerm} guarantees that except for Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l}, other participants cannot know the permutation Ï€ğœ‹\pi. After the initialization, all participants collaboratively permute âŸ¦ğ±âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ±\llbracket\mathbf{x}\rrbracket in 222 rounds. 5.2.4 Secure Decision Table Training Algorithm

In this section, we introduce how Privet combines the components introduced above to securely train a distributed decision table. Algorithm 6 (named as ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾\mathsf{SecTable}) describes this process. ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾\mathsf{SecTable} is the secure instantiation of Algorithm 1 and relies on the coordination of the secure components introduced above.

Algorithm 6 inputs the vertically partitioned datasets {ğ’ŸmNÃ—Jm}m=1nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘š1\{\mathcal{D}^{N\times J_{m}}_{m}\}^{n}_{m=1}, secret-shared label âŸ¦ğ²âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ²\llbracket\mathbf{y}\rrbracket, and aggregated inference results âŸ¦ğ²^âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§^ğ²\llbracket\mathbf{\hat{y}}\rrbracket from the previous round of training, and then outputs a distributed decision table. The Boolean tests at different levels of the decision table are held by different participants and the output values associated with each leaf node are stored in an secret-shared vector âŸ¦ğ°âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ°\llbracket\mathbf{w}\rrbracket.

At the beginning of Algorithm 6, P1,P2,â‹¯,Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n} calculate the secret-shared first and second-order gradient vectors (for the root node) (i.e., âŸ¦ğ âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ \llbracket\mathbf{g}\rrbracket and âŸ¦ğ¡âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ¡\llbracket\mathbf{h}\rrbracket at lines 3-8). After calculating the secret-shared gradients, Privet initializes a secret-shared vector âŸ¦ğ°âŸ§=âŸ¦ğŸ2DâŸ§\llbracket\mathbf{w}\rrbracket=\llbracket\mathbf{0}_{2^{D}}\rrbracket to store the 2Dsuperscript2ğ·2^{D} secret-shared output values. After that, a decision table will be built level by level. Similar to the functionality of ğ–¿ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½â€‹_â€‹ğ—Œğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–¿ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–½_ğ—Œğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{find\_split} in Algorithm 1, Privet securely selects the optimal test Fd<tdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘F_{d}<t_{d} at the dğ‘‘d-th level (dâˆˆ[0,Dâˆ’1]ğ‘‘0ğ·1d\in[0,D-1]). Specifically, the selection is made greedily: the learning algorithm first selects the best test for each feature (i.e., linesÂ 12-27) and then selects the optimal test among the Jğ½J selected candidate tests (i.e., linesÂ 28-30). It is noted that the selection here is made following that in the plaintext domain, which is introduced in Section 3.2, and the operations in the selection are substituted with secure operations and proposed components. For the Jğ½J candidate tests, we initialize a secret-shared vector âŸ¦ğˆâŸ§=âŸ¦ğŸJâŸ§\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket=\llbracket\mathbf{0}_{J}\rrbracket to store the score of each featureâ€™s best test. Besides, Privet uses a public vector ğœ¸=ğŸJğœ¸subscript0ğ½\boldsymbol{\gamma}=\mathbf{0}_{J} to record the bucket ID of each featureâ€™s best test.

For simplicity, the total Jğ½J features are numbered from 00 to Jâˆ’1ğ½1J-1. At the beginning of the loop for the jğ‘—j-th feature in Algorithm 6, the participant who holds the jğ‘—j-th feature first generates a permutation Ï€jsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘—\pi_{j} locally by sorting the values of the jğ‘—j-th feature (denoted by ğ’Ÿâ€‹(j)ğ’Ÿğ‘—\mathcal{D}(j)) in the ascending order, which will be used to securely permute the secret-shared gradient vectors associated with each node at this level. After that, a naive method is to permute the gradient vectors and then adapt the Exact Greedy Algorithm [35] to enumerate each training sample to find the best test. However, enumerating all training samples incurs heavy computation overhead. Moreover, it will incur prohibitively expensive communication overhead in the distributed setting, degrading the efficiency of the system.

We propose a component ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼\mathsf{SecDisc} (shown in Algorithm 5) to tackle this challenge and enable Privet to scale on larger datasets. Specifically, ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼\mathsf{SecDisc} inputs secret-shared gradient vectors âŸ¦ğ k,dâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\llbracket{\mathbf{g}^{k,d}}\rrbracket and âŸ¦ğ¡k,dâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ¡ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\llbracket{\mathbf{h}^{k,d}}\rrbracket associated with the kğ‘˜k-th node at the dğ‘‘d-th level. The secret-shared gradients in âŸ¦ğ k,dâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\llbracket{\mathbf{g}^{k,d}}\rrbracket and âŸ¦ğ¡k,dâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğ¡ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\llbracket{\mathbf{h}^{k,d}}\rrbracket are securely discretized into BğµB buckets and stored in secret-shared vectors âŸ¦ğœ¶k,dâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğœ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\llbracket\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{k,d}\rrbracket and âŸ¦ğœ·k,dâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§superscriptğœ·ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\llbracket\boldsymbol{\beta}^{k,d}\rrbracket, respectively. There are Bâˆ’1ğµ1B-1 intervals among the BğµB buckets and each corresponds to a candidate test. In this way, Privet only needs to select the best test from Bâˆ’1ğµ1B-1 candidate tests for each feature, instead of enumerating Nğ‘N samples, so as to save considerable computation and communication cost. In Privet, we initialize a secret-shared vector âŸ¦ğœ¹âŸ§=âŸ¦ğŸBâˆ’1âŸ§\llbracket\boldsymbol{\delta}\rrbracket=\llbracket\mathbf{0}_{B-1}\rrbracket for each feature to store the scores of the Bâˆ’1ğµ1B-1 candidate tests.

After securely discretizing gradients into BğµB buckets, the Bâˆ’1ğµ1B-1 candidate tests are evaluated to select the best test of the jğ‘—j-th feature. For the cğ‘c-th candidate test (câˆˆ[0,Bâˆ’2]ğ‘0ğµ2c\in[0,B-2]), the first c+1ğ‘1c+1 buckets are aggregated to get âŸ¦GlâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğºğ‘™\llbracket{G_{l}}\rrbracket and âŸ¦HlâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ»ğ‘™\llbracket{H_{l}}\rrbracket, which are the sum of gradients associated with the left child node, and the remaining Bâˆ’câˆ’1ğµğ‘1B-c-1 buckets are aggregated to get âŸ¦GrâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğºğ‘Ÿ\llbracket{G_{r}}\rrbracket and âŸ¦HrâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ»ğ‘Ÿ\llbracket{H_{r}}\rrbracket, which are the sum of gradients associated with the right child node. The impurity of each nodeâ€™s two child nodes is securely computed following Eq. 6 and then aggregated together to produce the secret-shared score of the cğ‘c-th candidate test following Eq. 5. The division needed in Eq. 6 can be securely calculated with our proposed secure component ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SDiv} in Section 5.2.2. Then for the jğ‘—j-th feature, we will have Bâˆ’1ğµ1B-1 secret-shared scores stored in âŸ¦ğœ¹âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğœ¹\llbracket\boldsymbol{\delta}\rrbracket.

After getting the Bâˆ’1ğµ1B-1 scores, we need to select the best test that achieves the minimum score, which requires a method to securely calculate the index of the minimum value in a secret-shared vector. To tackle this challenge, Privet introduces a component ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡\mathsf{SecArgmin}, which inputs a secret-shared vector and outputs the index of the minimum value of the vector. It is noted that the key operation in the function Argmin is comparison, which is not naturally supported in the secret sharing domain. The secure comparison operation in our Privet is introduced as follows. Given two secret-shared values âŸ¦AâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ´\llbracket A\rrbracket and âŸ¦BâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğµ\llbracket B\rrbracket, Privet first locally decomposes âŸ¦Aâˆ’BâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ´ğµ\llbracket A-B\rrbracket into bits, and then inputs these bits into a parallel prefix adder (PPA) to securely compute the secret-shared most significant bit (MSB) of âŸ¦Aâˆ’BâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ´ğµ\llbracket A-B\rrbracket, inspired by [47, 48]. After that, we convert the secret-shared MSB into the arithmetic sharing domain by the method in [45], so as to get the secret-shared result of the secure comparison. Based on the secure comparison method introduced above, ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡\mathsf{SecArgmin} inputs the secret-shared vector âŸ¦ğœ¹âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğœ¹\llbracket\boldsymbol{\delta}\rrbracket and then outputs bucket ID qâˆˆ[0,Bâˆ’2]ğ‘0ğµ2q\in[0,B-2] of the jğ‘—j-th featureâ€™s best test in the plaintext. In Privet, all participants can learn the produced bucket ID in the training stage, but only the participant who owns the jğ‘—j-th feature can get the threshold of the jğ‘—j-th featureâ€™s best test. Since the values of the jğ‘—j-th feature (denoted by ğ’Ÿâ€‹(j)ğ’Ÿğ‘—\mathcal{D}(j)) is sorted in ascending order, the participant who owns the jğ‘—j-th feature can get the split threshold via looking up the sorted values (i.e., Ï€jâ€‹[ğ’Ÿâ€‹(j)]subscriptğœ‹ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ’Ÿğ‘—\pi_{j}[\mathcal{D}(j)]) with index (q+1)Ã—(N/B)ğ‘1ğ‘ğµ(q+1)\times(N/B). Other participants cannot deduce the split threshold because the jğ‘—j-th feature is kept locally by its owner and unavailable to them.

To select the optimal test of all features, Privet lets the participants record the jğ‘—j-th featureâ€™s best bucket ID qğ‘q and secret-shared minimum split score âŸ¦ğœ¹qâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğœ¹ğ‘\llbracket\boldsymbol{\delta}_{q}\rrbracket at the jğ‘—j-th position of ğœ¸ğœ¸\boldsymbol{\gamma} and âŸ¦ğˆâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğˆ\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket, respectively (i.e., lines 25-26 in Algorithm 6). Recall that for the Jğ½J features, we use ğœ¸ğœ¸\boldsymbol{\gamma} and âŸ¦ğˆâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğˆ\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket to store the bucket ID and split score of each featureâ€™s best test. The Jğ½J indices of ğœ¸ğœ¸\boldsymbol{\gamma} and âŸ¦ğˆâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğˆ\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket correspond to Jğ½J features, respectively. After enumerating Jğ½J features, Jğ½J scores are stored in âŸ¦ğˆâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğˆ\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket and ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡\mathsf{SecArgmin} is needed to be called again on âŸ¦ğˆâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğˆ\llbracket\boldsymbol{\sigma}\rrbracket. The output is the split feature Fdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘F_{d} of the optimal test, which is known by all participants. The optimal bucket ID qdsubscriptğ‘ğ‘‘q_{d} of the split feature can then be retrieved with Fdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘F_{d} from ğœ¸ğœ¸\boldsymbol{\gamma} (line 29). After that, the participant who owns the split feature Fdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘F_{d} looks up the its sorted values Ï€Fdâ€‹[ğ’Ÿâ€‹(Fd)]subscriptğœ‹subscriptğ¹ğ‘‘delimited-[]ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘\pi_{F_{d}}[\mathcal{D}(F_{d})] with index (qd+1)Ã—(N/B)subscriptğ‘ğ‘‘1ğ‘ğµ(q_{d}+1)\times(N/B) to get the split threshold tdsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘t_{d}.

After learning the dğ‘‘d-th test Fd<tdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘F_{d}<t_{d}, the participant who owns Fd<tdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘F_{d}<t_{d} cooperates with other participants to securely split all the nodes at the dğ‘‘d-th level with ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SecSplit} to create a new level (line 32). A decision table in Privet is learned level by level in this way. At the Dğ·D-th level, Privet securely calculates output values for the 2Dsuperscript2ğ·2^{D} leaf nodes following Eq. 3 (i.e., lines 34-37 in Algorithm 6), where the division is securely calculated with ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SDiv} in Section 5.2.2. Finally, ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–³ğ–ºğ–»ğ—…ğ–¾\mathsf{SecTable} outputs a distributed decision table consisting of Dğ·D tests and 2Dsuperscript2ğ·2^{D} secret-shared output values. Specifically, all participants know the split feature Fdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘F_{d} at the dğ‘‘d-th level where dâˆˆ[0,Dâˆ’1]ğ‘‘0ğ·1d\in[0,D-1], but each split threshold tdsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘t_{d} is only available to the participant who owns the feature Fdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘F_{d}.

5.3 Secure Distributed Decision Table Inference

In Privet, each decision table in the ensemble learned in the secure training phase is held by the participants in a distributed manner, where each participant holds a part of it. Recall that in our secure VFL framework (Algorithm 2), once a distributed decision table ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} is securely learned in a certain round, we need to perform secure inference over the training data using ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T}. The the produced inference results at this round will be securely aggreagted with previous inference results for use in securely training a new distributed decision table in the next round. To prevent the partial model and local data on each participant from leaking during the secure inference process, we propose a secure distributed decision table inference protocol ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer}, which relies on secure multiplication of indicator vectors to conduct privacy-preserving inference, as shown in Algorithm 7. ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer} allows the participants to cooperatively perform secure inference on their local data utilizing the distributed ensemble and produce secret-shared inference results while keeping the local data and partial model not unavailable to other participants throughout the inference process. We introduce the design of ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer} as follows.

To securely produce the inference result of a vertically partitioned sample {ğ±J1,ğ±J2,â‹¯,ğ±Jn}superscriptğ±subscriptğ½1superscriptğ±subscriptğ½2â‹¯superscriptğ±subscriptğ½ğ‘›\{\mathbf{x}^{J_{1}},\mathbf{x}^{J_{2}},\cdots,\mathbf{x}^{J_{n}}\}, the participant Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l} who owns the test Fd<tdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘F_{d}<t_{d} at the dğ‘‘d-th level (dâˆˆ[0,Dâˆ’1]ğ‘‘0ğ·1d\in[0,D-1]) locally generates a leaf indicator (denoted by ğ®dsubscriptğ®ğ‘‘\mathbf{u}_{d}) by comparing the sampleâ€™s feature value of Fdsubscriptğ¹ğ‘‘F_{d} (represented as ğ±Jlâ€‹(Fd)superscriptğ±subscriptğ½ğ‘™subscriptğ¹ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}^{J_{l}}(F_{d})) with the split threshold tdsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‘t_{d}. After that, the leaf indicator ğ®dsubscriptğ®ğ‘‘\mathbf{u}_{d} is secret-shared to other participants. The inference result could then be obliviously calculated by secure element-wise multiplication between the Dğ·D secret-shared leaf indicators {âŸ¦ğ®iâŸ§}i=0Dâˆ’1\{\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{i}\rrbracket\}_{i=0}^{D-1} and the secret-shared vector âŸ¦ğ°âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ°\llbracket\mathbf{w}\rrbracket of decision tableâ€™s output values. We take a 333-dimensional decision table to present the details of model distribution and ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer} in Fig. 4. Without loss of generality, we assume that the tests are â€œHâ€‹eâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹hâ€‹t<170ğ»ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡170Height<170â€, â€œWâ€‹eâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹hâ€‹t<60ğ‘Šğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡60Weight<60â€, and â€œSâ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹aâ€‹râ€‹y<10000ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘¦10000Salary<10000â€, held by participants P1,P2,P3subscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2subscriptğ‘ƒ3P_{1},P_{2},P_{3} , respectively, and the eight leavesâ€™ output values are secret-shared among nğ‘›n participants. In Fig. 4, it is noted that the exact test is only visible to the participant owning the corresponding feature, e.g., only P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} knows the test â€œHâ€‹eâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹hâ€‹t<170ğ»ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡170Height<170â€ at the 00-th level.

We take the inference of sample (â€œHâ€‹eâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹hâ€‹t=175ğ»ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡175Height=175â€, â€œWâ€‹eâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹hâ€‹t=55ğ‘Šğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡55Weight=55â€, â€œSâ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹aâ€‹râ€‹y=11000ğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘¦11000Salary=11000â€) as an example. The three features are vertically partitioned and held by P1,P2,P3subscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2subscriptğ‘ƒ3P_{1},P_{2},P_{3}, respectively. For the first test â€œHâ€‹eâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹hâ€‹t<170ğ»ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡170Height<170â€, P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} locally compares â€œHâ€‹eâ€‹iâ€‹gâ€‹hâ€‹t=175ğ»ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡175Height=175â€ with the threshold 170 and generate leaf indicator vector ğ®0=(0,0,0,0,1,1,1,1)subscriptğ®000001111\mathbf{u}_{0}=(0,0,0,0,1,1,1,1) to guide the inference path because 175>170175170175>170. Similarly, we can get ğ®1=(1,1,0,0,1,1,0,0)subscriptğ®111001100\mathbf{u}_{1}=(1,1,0,0,1,1,0,0) and ğ®2=(0,1,0,1,0,1,0,1)subscriptğ®201010101\mathbf{u}_{2}=(0,1,0,1,0,1,0,1). Each leaf indicator vector is then secret-shared among all participants. Recall that in the basic decision table inference introduced in Section 3, the comparisons required by different Boolean tests are parallelized to accelerate inference due to the oblivious tree structure. Although the learned decision tables in the ensemble in Privet are distributed and secret-shared, their oblivious structure remains unchanged, and thus operations at different levels can still be parallelized. After the sharing of leaf indicator vectors, the inference result of this sample can be obliviously calculated by element-wise multiplication as follows: âŸ¦ğ®0âŸ§Ã—âŸ¦ğ®1âŸ§Ã—âŸ¦ğ®2âŸ§Ã—âŸ¦ğ°âŸ§\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{0}\rrbracket\times\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{1}\rrbracket\times\llbracket\mathbf{u}_{2}\rrbracket\times\llbracket\mathbf{w}\rrbracket. In this way, each participant will not know which path in the distributed decision table is used during the secure inference process.

Remark. We note that there are some existing secure distributed decision tree inference methods [7, 8] in the VFL setting. However, they are not well suited for the required secure distributed decision table inference in Privet. At a high level, these two works and Privet share the common approach of using indicator vectors to enable secure inference. However, the inherent structural differences between decision tables and decision trees result in different methods of generating and utilizing indicator vectors for guiding the inference paths during privacy-preserving inference. In secure distributed decision tree inference of [7, 8], each internal node is associated with an indicator vector, and the inference result is produced by secure multiplication of these indicator vectors. In contrast, for secure distributed decision table inference, each level in the decision table is associated with an indicator vector. As a result, existing secure distributed decision tree inference methods cannot be efficiently extended to secure distributed decision table inference. For instance, with our proposed ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer} protocol and a decision table with a dimension of D=6ğ·6D=6, only six indicator vectors and six secure multiplications are needed. However, applying the method from [7, 8] to our target problem would require 26âˆ’1superscript2612^{6}-1 indicator vectors and 63 secure multiplications, resulting in poor efficiency. Moreover, the secure distributed tree inference method in [8] is not applicable in our setting because it targets a two-party setting, while Privet aims to support an arbitrary number of participants.

6 Security Analysis

Privet utilizes standard secret sharing techniques [49] to properly encrypt the intermediate information during both training and inference phases and the secret shares are uniformly distributed in a ring â„¤2Qsubscriptâ„¤superscript2ğ‘„\mathbb{Z}_{2^{Q}}. In addition, throughout the VFL procedure, the feature data owned by each participant is kept locally. We follow the standard simulation-based paradigm [50] to analyze the security of Privet. We first define the ideal functionality of our target privacy-preserving VFL with gradient boosted decision tables as follows.

Definition 1.

The ideal functionality â„±VDTsubscriptâ„±VDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} of privacy-preserving VFL with gradient boosted decision tables is formulated as follows:

-Input. The input to the â„±VDTsubscriptâ„±VDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} consists of datasets {ğ’ŸmNÃ—Jm}m=1nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ’Ÿğ‘subscriptğ½ğ‘šğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘š1\{\mathcal{D}^{N\times J_{m}}_{m}\}^{n}_{m=1} and the label set ğ²ğ²\mathbf{y} from the participants P1,P2,â‹¯,Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n}.

-Computation. Upon receiving the above input, the ideal functionality â„±VDTsubscriptâ„±VDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} performs training of gradient boosted decision tables and produces the trained model VDT, which consists of Tğ‘‡T decision tables.

-Output. The ideal functionality â„±VDTsubscriptâ„±VDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} broadcasts the split feature in the decision table to all participants, but only sends the split threshold to the participant who holds the corresponding split feature. Additionally, the â„±VDTsubscriptâ„±VDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} splits the output values into nğ‘›n secret shares and then distributes them to the participants P1,P2,â‹¯,Pnsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2â‹¯subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘›P_{1},P_{2},\cdots,P_{n}.

Definition 2.

A protocol Î Î \Pi securely realizes the ideal functionality â„±VDTsubscriptâ„±VDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} in the semi-honest adversary setting if a semi-honest participant does not learn any information about other participantsâ€™ private data and partial model. Formally, let ğ–µğ—‚ğ–¾ğ—PmÎ subscriptsuperscriptğ–µğ—‚ğ–¾ğ—Î subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘š\mathsf{View}^{\Pi}_{P_{m}} represent participant Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šP_{m}â€™s view during the execution of Î Î \Pi. Formally, there should exist a PPT simulator, which can generate a simulated view ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†PmÎ subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Î subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘š\mathsf{Sim}^{\Pi}_{P_{m}} such that ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†PmÎ subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Î subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘š\mathsf{Sim}^{\Pi}_{P_{m}} is indistinguishable from ğ–µğ—‚ğ–¾ğ—PmÎ subscriptsuperscriptğ–µğ—‚ğ–¾ğ—Î subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘š\mathsf{View}^{\Pi}_{P_{m}}.

Theorem 1.

Our Privet securely realizes the ideal functionality â„±VDTsubscriptâ„±VDT\mathcal{F}_{\text{{VDT}}} against a semi-honest adversary who can statically corrupt a subset of Ï„ğœ\tau participants (Ï„â‰¤nâˆ’1ğœğ‘›1\tau\leq n-1) according to Definition 2.

Proof.

If the simulator for each sub-protocol exists, then our complete protocol is secure [51, 52, 53]. As presented before, Privet consists of several secure sub-protocols: 1) secure division ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SDiv}; 2) secure Sigmoid ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½\mathsf{SecSigmoid}; 3) secure node splitting ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SecSplit}; 4) secure distributed decision table inference ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer}; 5) secure discretization ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼\mathsf{SecDisc}; 6) secure Argmin ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡\mathsf{SecArgmin}. We use ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Pmğ–·subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–·subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘š\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{X}}_{P_{m}} as the simulator which can generate Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šP_{m}â€™s view in sub-protocol ğ–·ğ–·\mathsf{X} (ğ–·âˆˆ{ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—,ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½,ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—,ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹,ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼,ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡})ğ–·ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡(\mathsf{X}\in\{\mathsf{SDiv},\mathsf{SecSigmoid},\mathsf{SecSplit},\mathsf{SecInfer},\mathsf{SecDisc},\mathsf{SecArgmin}\}) on corresponding input and output. Obviously, the simulators for ğ–·âˆˆ{ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—,ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½,ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡}ğ–·ğ–²ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—€ğ—†ğ—ˆğ—‚ğ–½ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡\mathsf{X}\in\{\mathsf{SDiv,SecSigmoid,SecArgmin}\} must exist, because they are comprised of basic operations in the secret sharing domain[49]. In the execution of these three protocols, even if a subset of Ï„ğœ\tau participants is corrupted, the honest participantsâ€™ private data will not be leaked due to the security guarantee of additive secret sharing[45]. In addition, when revealing the index of the minimum value in a secret-shared vector to all participants in ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡\mathsf{SecArgmin}, the simulator can adjust the shares of the result such that the revealed index is indeed the value received from the ideal functionality, and thus the simulator of ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ– ğ—‹ğ—€ğ—†ğ—‚ğ—‡\mathsf{SecArgmin} exists. Therefore, Privet is secure if the simulators for the remaining sub-protocols exist, i.e., ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SecSplit} in Section 5.2.1, ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer} in Section 5.3, ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼\mathsf{SecDisc} in Section 5.2.3. We next provide the existence of the simulators for the remaining sub-protocols. âˆ

Theorem 2.

The simulators for sub-protocols ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SecSplit} and ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer} exsit.

Proof.

The sub-protocols ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SecSplit} and ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer} both require that the participant who holds the split generates indicator vectors locally and then secret-shares them to other participants. For simplicity, we assume that Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l} holds the split threshold and collaborates with Pmâ‰ lsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šğ‘™P_{m\neq l} to split the node and conduct inference. We then prove the existence of the simulators ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Plğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecSplit}}_{P_{l}}, ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Plğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecInfer}}_{P_{l}} for Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l} and the simulators ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Pmâ‰ lğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šğ‘™\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecSplit}}_{P_{m\neq l}}, ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Pmâ‰ lğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šğ‘™\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecInfer}}_{P_{m\neq l}} for Pmâ‰ lsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šğ‘™P_{m\neq l} due to their different computation. We also note that there is no difference in the simulation between AP and PP due to their role equivalence in the execution of ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—\mathsf{SecSplit} and ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹\mathsf{SecInfer}.

    ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Plğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–²ğ—‰ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecSplit}}_{P_{l}}, ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Plğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¨ğ—‡ğ–¿ğ–¾ğ—‹subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecInfer}}_{P_{l}} for Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l}: The simulator is simple since Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l} only secret-shares its local indicator vectors and perform secure multiplications on the secret-shared vectors. Theorem 3.

The simulator for the sub-protocol ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼\mathsf{SecDisc} exists.

In ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–¯ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—†\mathsf{SecPerm}, for simplicity, we assume that Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l} sorts the values for a feature locally to generate a permutation Ï€ğœ‹\pi. We then prove the existence of the simulator ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Plğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecDisc}}_{P_{l}} for Plsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘™P_{l} and the simulator ğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†Pmâ‰ lğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼subscriptsuperscriptğ–²ğ—‚ğ—†ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šğ‘™\mathsf{Sim}^{\mathsf{SecDisc}}_{P_{m\neq l}} for Pmâ‰ lsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šğ‘™P_{m\neq l} due to their different computation. Similarly, since the role equivalence of AP and PP in the execution of ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼ğ–²ğ–¾ğ–¼ğ–£ğ—‚ğ—Œğ–¼\mathsf{SecDisc}, there is no difference in the analysis for them.

7 Experiments

7.1 Setup

We implement our protocols in Python. All experiments are performed on a workstation with 16 Intel I7- 10700K cores, 64GB RAM, and 1TB SSD external storage, running Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS. It is worth mentioning that the practice of evaluating VFL algorithms on a single machine also exists in prior works [10, 7, 8, 54]. We also note that in practice, it is not common to have VFL scenarios with more than four participants since it could be hard to bring together many enterprises [9, 55]. Therefore, in our experiments, we follow prior works[7, 55, 9, 56] to conduct experiments with four participants. The communication between participants on the workstation is emulated by the loopback filesystem, where the delay is set to 5 ms and bandwidth is set to 100 Mbps.

Datasets. We use three real-world datasets to evaluate the accuracy and efficiency of Privet and three synthetic datasets to further evaluate the scalability of Privet. The synthetic datasets are generated with sklearn444https://scikit-learn.org/stable/ library. Table II summarizes the statistics of the six datasets. We divide each dataset into two parts for training and testing respectively according to the ratio of 8:2. In addition to the preprocessing in the above, each dataset is split and distributed to all participants vertically and evenly. Similar to previous works on VFL [11, 8], we assume that the records in each participantâ€™s database have been properly aligned beforehand.

Protocol instantiation. Our protocols are instantiated using the following parameter settings. We use the ring â„¤264subscriptâ„¤superscript264\mathbb{Z}_{2^{64}} with the number of precision bits l=20ğ‘™20l=20. The number of iterations for the reciprocal approximation is set to 20 (with 1/Y=1/2201ğ‘Œ1superscript2201/Y=1/2^{20} as the initialization). For approximating the exponential function, we set 2n=4superscript2ğ‘›42^{n}=4, thus the approximation requires logâ¡2n=2superscript2ğ‘›2\log 2^{n}=2 rounds of multiplication. The hyper-parameters are public to all participants. We fix Î»=1ğœ†1\lambda=1 of Eq. 6 and vary the public parameter Tğ‘‡T (the number of decision tables), BğµB (the number of buckets), and Dğ·D (the dimension of decision tables) in our experiments to demonstrate the utility, efficiency, and scalability of Privet.

It is noted that to handle real numbers for secure computation, we follow the common practice of fixed-point representation, where real numbers are scaled by a factor of 2lsuperscript2ğ‘™2^{l} (lğ‘™l represents the number of precision bits) and then rounded. As a result, when two scaled values are multiplied, the result is under a scaling factor of 22â€‹lsuperscript22ğ‘™2^{2l}. Therefore, truncation is required to scale down the multiplication result, making its scaling factor 2lsuperscript2ğ‘™2^{l} again. Privet resorts to the method in [45] to support secure truncation on a result âŸ¦zâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ‘§\llbracket z\rrbracket produced from secret-shared multiplication, which works as follows. Firstly, the secret sharing of the number of wraps (denoted by âŸ¦Î¸zâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğœƒğ‘§\llbracket\theta_{z}\rrbracket) in zğ‘§z needs to be computed, which is subject to Î¸z=(âˆ‘m=1nâŸ¨zâŸ©mâˆ’z)/2Qsubscriptğœƒğ‘§subscriptsuperscriptğ‘›ğ‘š1subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘§ğ‘šğ‘§superscript2ğ‘„\theta_{z}=(\sum^{n}_{m=1}\langle z\rangle_{m}-z)/2^{Q}. It is noted that to count the number of wrap rounds in this truncation protocol, computing the sum of shares (represented in the form of âˆ‘m=1nâŸ¨zâŸ©msubscriptsuperscriptğ‘›ğ‘š1subscriptdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘§ğ‘š\sum^{n}_{m=1}\langle z\rangle_{m}) does not involve modular arithmetic. The computation of âŸ¦Î¸zâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğœƒğ‘§\llbracket\theta_{z}\rrbracket proceeds as follows.
